body:
Comment 4: 
Brad: I do mean only for interfaces, yes.  When an interface value is nil (not just
holds a nil value of some type, but actually nil) then there is no method.

Alan: I understand that point but it doesn't seem precisely correct to me.  If taken
literally it would mean that
    var err error
    f := err.Error
    if f == nil { println("nil") } else { println("not nil") }
would print "not nil".  That seems strange.  If a method value of a nil interface
doesn't panic, it seems to me that it must return nil.
